itemDescription: British military interpreter in Lhasa, and a writer

wikipedia_page.main: Lieutenant-Colonel Sir William Frederick Travers O'Connor  (30 July 1870 – 14 December 1943) was an Irish diplomat and officer in the British and British Indian armies. He is remembered for his travels in Asia, cartography, study and publication of local cultures and language, his actions on the Younghusband expedition to Tibet, Royal Geographic Society council member, member of the Royal Automobile Club and for his work negotiating and signing the Nepal–Britain Treaty of 1923.

response: *William Frederick Travers O'Connor (1870–1943), Irish diplomat involved in the British expedition to Tibet and the Nepal–Britain Treaty of 1923
A Type 69 was one of the first two motor vehicles in Tibet, imported by William Frederick Travers O'Connor in 1907 and later given as a gift to the Thubten Choekyi Nyima, the 9th Panchen Lama.
